description: From Middle English disareyen (“to disarray”), from Middle French desarroyer, from Old French desareer, from des- (“dis-”) + areer (“to array”).

entries.meaning: Lack of array or regular order; disorder; confusion.

verbs.description: disarray (third-person singular simple present disarrays, present participle disarraying, simple past and past participle disarrayed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To throw into disorder; to break the array of.
examples: Who with fiery steeds / Oft disarray'd the foes in battle ranged.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take off the dress of; to unrobe.
